 Our nation was founded by guys who fought a civil war against the government that tried to seize their weapons. They protested tax hikes and unfair taxation and lack of representation, but when the government tried to seize their weapons, they started shooting. 
 
 What were they trying to seize? The arsenals at Lexington and Concord did not contain fowling pieces, rifles, and muzzles. It held cannons, artillery pieces, and thousands of pounds of powder for them. The potential sporting uses for such weapons are non existent, and they were not community owned...they were the personal property of individuals who opted to store them in the community arsenal because frankly storing a few thousands lbs of black powder in your basement is not advisable. 
 
 Even the small arms they tried to seize were not the weapons used for hunting. They were, at the time, fearsom military rifles. Most were not accurate enough for hunting, but they could be loaded without wadding or ramming the load. You fired them, ran a patch down the barrel to ensure there was no burnign powder left (which would make the next part exciting), poured in your powder, tapped the butt on the ground to settle the powder, dropped in the ball, tapped it again, and fired. During a time where most weapons required a patched round, the firing rates you could achieve with a weapon like that was very nearly incomprehensible. They were the M-16 of their day. 
 
 The guys who wrote the second amendment and later sold it to the American people...THAT is what they were trying to protect for us...the right to own artillery pieces and guns that were, at the time, referred to as "death machines" by those who opposed them (there have always been anti gunners). 
 
 I point all this out to remind people that the second amendment is not about hunting or target shooting. It is only marginally connected to home defense and probably has nothing at all to do with concealed carry. The second amendment is about blowing your fellow man to hell if it becomes necessary. It is about defending the nation from both foreign enemies and, if necessary, from its government.
